title: Jephthah's Vow and Victory
shortSummary: Judges 11 recounts the story of Jephthah, a mighty warrior rejected by his family but called to lead Israel against the Ammonites. The chapter highlights themes of leadership, faith, and the consequences of rash vows, culminating in Jephthah's tragic vow and the annual mourning for his daughter.
timeline: c. 1375-1050 BC - Period of the Judges in Israel

keyCharacters.name: Jephthah
keyCharacters.description: A mighty warrior of Gilead, initially rejected by his family, who becomes Israel’s leader to fight the Ammonites and makes a consequential vow to the LORD.

keyCharacters.name: Elders of Gilead
keyCharacters.description: Leaders of the Gileadites who seek Jephthah’s help to lead them in battle against the Ammonites despite previously rejecting him.

keyCharacters.name: King of the Children of Ammon
keyCharacters.description: The adversary who claims Israel unlawfully took his land, provoking the conflict that Jephthah confronts.

keyCharacters.name: Jephthah’s Daughter
keyCharacters.description: Jephthah’s only child who tragically becomes the subject of his vow and mourns her virginity before her sacrifice.

definitions.definition: A woman engaged in sexual immorality; in this context, Jephthah’s mother was a prostitute, which caused his brothers to reject him.
A solemn promise made to God, often involving a commitment or sacrifice, which must be fulfilled according to biblical teaching.
A type of sacrifice in which an animal or object is completely consumed by fire as an act of worship and atonement to God.
A significant gathering place or high place in Israel where Jephthah made his vow before the LORD.

outline.heading: Jephthah’s Background and Rejection
outline.description: Jephthah, born of a harlot, is rejected by his half-brothers and driven away, illustrating themes of rejection and God’s use of unlikely leaders.

outline.heading: Call to Leadership and Negotiation with Ammon
outline.description: The elders of Gilead seek Jephthah to lead them against the Ammonites. Jephthah negotiates with the Ammonite king, asserting Israel’s God-given right to the land.

outline.heading: Jephthah’s Vow and Victory
outline.description: Filled with the Spirit of the LORD, Jephthah makes a vow promising a burnt offering if victorious. God grants victory over the Ammonites.

outline.heading: The Tragic Fulfillment of Jephthah’s Vow
outline.description: Jephthah’s only daughter meets him with joy, but he is devastated by his vow. She accepts her fate, and Israel commemorates her annually, highlighting the cost of rash vows.

application: Trust God’s timing and sovereignty even when rejected or overlooked by others, as God can use unlikely individuals for His purposes.
Be cautious and prayerful before making vows to God, understanding the seriousness of commitments made in His name.
Seek to resolve conflicts with wisdom and scriptural truth, as Jephthah did in his negotiation with the Ammonites.
Honor God through obedience, even when it involves personal sacrifice, trusting His greater plan and justice.

keyVerses.text: Then the Spirit of the LORD came upon Jephthah, and he passed over Gilead, and Manasseh, and passed over Mizpeh of Gilead, and from Mizpeh of Gilead he passed over unto the children of Ammon.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the divine empowerment of Jephthah for leadership and victory, showing the Spirit’s role in God’s chosen leaders.

keyVerses.text: And Jephthah vowed a vow unto the LORD, and said, If thou shalt without fail deliver the children of Ammon into mine hands, Then it shall be, that whatsoever cometh forth of the doors of my house to meet me, when I return in peace from the children of Ammon, shall surely be the LORD'S, and I will offer it up for a burnt offering.
keyVerses.significance: These verses reveal the seriousness and danger of rash vows, emphasizing the need for careful commitment to God.

keyVerses.text: And it came to pass, when he saw her, that he rent his clothes, and said, Alas, my daughter! thou hast brought me very low, and thou art one of them that trouble me: for I have opened my mouth unto the LORD, and I cannot go back.
keyVerses.significance: Jephthah’s lament shows the tragic consequences of his vow and the weight of promises made to God.

keyVerses.text: That the daughters of Israel went yearly to lament the daughter of Jephthah the Gileadite four days in a year.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the lasting memorial of Jephthah’s daughter, reminding believers of the cost of vows and the importance of honoring God’s word.
